questions.text: Which of the following vitamins, when infused in supraphysiological doses, cause macular oedema and macular cysts?
questions.solution:
Macular cysts and oedema may develop in patients due to the infusion of supraphysiological doses of vitamin B3 (niacin toxicity).

The toxic effects of niacin include:

  • Flushing associated with skin dryness, itching, paresthesia, and headache. These effects may be seen with even a low dose of 30mg/day. Premedication with aspirin alleviates these symptoms (as these symptoms are mediated by prostaglandins)
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Hepatic toxicity, which presents as jaundice with elevated AST and ALT levels.
  • Fulminant hepatitis requiring liver transplantation.
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Macular edema and macular cysts.

questions.text: A baby with a birth weight of 1400g is started on fortified breast milk. This should be supplemented with:
questions.solution:
Fortified breast milk should be supplemented with iron.

For very low birth weight (VLBW) infants, fortified breast milk is essential for their growth. It contains nutrients like calcium, phosphorus, folate, and vitamins. However, breast milk lacks sufficient iron. So, VLBW infants need separate iron supplementation in liquid form to prevent anemia and support healthy brain development. 

Multinutrient supplementation is recommended for very low birth weight infants till they reach 40 weeks gestational age. This can be achieved by supplementing individual nutrients or fortification of the expressed breast milk with Human milk fortifiers (HMF).

All term babies and babies >1500 g can feed on breast milk without the need of HMFs. Babies should be supplemented with vitamin D and iron separately, as breast milk is lacking in these nutrients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with bone pain, headache and vomiting. The clinician suspects that these are due to increased intracranial pressure. On radiograph, increased density in metaphyseal region and sub- periosteal calcification is visible. Rest of the clinical examination is normal. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypervitaminosis D and A cause metabolic bone disease. An increased vitamin A level in the body can manifest in the form of pseudotumor cerebri (condition of increased intracranial pressure despite the absence of any pathology).

The increased density in metaphyseal region is due to excessive mineralization of bone.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is wrongly matched with their associated enzymes?

choices.text: Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) : FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test
Vitamin C  : Serum methyl malonate level

questions.solution:
Option D is wrongly matched as Vitamin B12 is associated with serum methyl malonyl levels and not Vitamin C. 

There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (Homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

The below figure shows B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase. Its deficiency may cause  folate trap.

Other options:

Option A: Thiamine pyrophosphate (Vit B1) is the cofactor of transketolase. Transketolase and transaldolase are involved in the nonoxidative phase of the HMP pathway.

Option B: Riboflavin deficiency is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).

Option C: FIGLU is converted to L-Glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine. The FIGLU excretion test is used to detect folic acid deficiency.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

questions.text: A young boy presented with fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth as shown below. On investigation, he had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is deficient here?
questions.solution:
Clinical presentation of this patient showing cheilosis and stomatitis, combined with low RBC glutathione reductase activity is consistent with riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

The deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  1. Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin
  2. Glossitis: tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue)
  3. Eyes: keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation
  4. Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, Anemia

The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase, by FAD added in vitro (this test is specific for riboflavin deficiency).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fat-soluble vitamins is true?

choices.text: Vitamin C is a fat soluble vitamin
Stored in the liver and the adipose tissue

questions.solution:
Fat-soluble vitamins are stored in the liver and adipose tissue.

Vitamins can be broadly classified into two categories:

  • Fat-soluble vitamins: Vitamins A, D, E, K
  • Water-soluble vitamins:  Vitamin B complex and Vitamin C

Few properties of fat-soluble vitamins:

  • Hydrophobic in nature
  • Transported in blood by the lipoproteins, such as chylomicrons
  • Stored in the liver and the adipose tissue 

Conditions affecting the digestion and absorption of the lipid-soluble vitamins causing deficiency of these vitamins include: a very low-fat diet, steatorrhea, and disorders of the biliary system.

questions.text:
A patient comes to you with vitamin D deficiency. You advise the patient to take a walk under sufficient sunlight everyday. What is the correct sequence of products formed during vitamin D synthesis?
  1. 7-dehydrocholesterol
  2. Cholecalciferol
  3. 25-hydroxycholecalciferol
  4. 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of products formed during vitamin D synthesis is 1-2-3-4.

Vitamin D is obtained by synthesis in the skin with adequate sunlight exposure or dietary supplementation. It helps in regulating calcium absorption and homeostasis. Deficiency results in rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults and is a common problem in areas with inadequate sunlight.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is:

  1. Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol is nonenzymatically converted to previtamin D on exposure to ultraviolet light. It is converted to cholecalciferol, which then enters the bloodstream.
  2. Liver: Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol), which is bound to a vitamin D-binding globulin and released into the bloodstream. This is the main storage form of vitamin D. 
  3. Kidney: 25-hydroxyvitamin D is further hydroxylated to form 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). This is the biologically active form of vitamin D. In some cases, it can also undergo 24-hydroxylation to form an inactive metabolite called 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D.

The steps of vitamin D synthesis are summarized below.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a past medical history of generalized seizures controlled with phenytoin therapy. She had mild pallor on physical examination. Lab values reveal Hb -  9.8 g/dl, MCV - 106 fL, Platelets - 1,80,000/cu.mm, leukocytes - 7800/cu.mm. Which of the following supplementations could have prevented this anemia?
questions.solution:
This patient has mild megaloblastic anemia (high MCV), probably due to chronic phenytoin therapy. Some anti-epileptic drugs like phenytoin, phenobarbital can cause megaloblastic anemia by impairing absorption of folate in the small intestine. Folic acid supplementation can prevent this condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented with chronic pain in the lower back and knees. On physical examination, there were black pigmentary deposits on the sclera of both eyes and on the fingers and nailbeds. The urine turned black on exposure to Benedict's reagent and showed large amounts of a particular metabolite which is responsible. Identify the metabolite from the image below
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of alkaptonuria, which is characterised by excretion of the metabolite homogentisate (marked as 2 in the flowchart) in urine.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism. It occurs due to a defect in homogentisate oxidase (which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate) leading to the accumulation of homogentisate. The excreted homogentisate in urine makes it appear black when it gets oxidized on exposure to air or an oxidizing agent.

Accumulation of oxidized homogentisic acid pigment (benzoquinone acetate) in joints and connective tissues leads to arthritis and connective tissue pigmentation respectively. This is known as ochronosis. Pigmentation of heart valves, larynx, tympanic membranes, and skin, with occasional renal pigment calculi, can also be seen.

Most patients are diagnosed early based on the darkening of urine with standing or the addition of alkali. Around the age of 30 years, gray-brown pigmentation of sclera and generalized darkening of the concha, anthelix and helix of the ear is seen.Some patients present in middle age with a degenerative joint disease (ochronotic arthritis) with pain, stiffness, and limitation of motion of the lower back, hips, knees, and shoulders. Small joints are usually spared.

Treatment:

  • Symptomatic treatment with pain medications, spinal surgery, and arthroplasty 
  • Ascorbic acid and protein restriction 
  • Nitisinone - reduces urinary excretion of homogentisic acid and delays progression of the disease.

The images below show pigmentation of the skin and an x-ray of the spine that shows calcification of intervertebral discs, both symptoms of ochronosis.

Image showing darkening of urine on standing:

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals?
questions.solution:
Excess of selenium causes alkali disease in livestock.

Clinical types of Selenium intoxication 

  • acute selenosis
  • subacute selenosis (i.e., blind staggers type)
  • chronic selenosis (i.e., alkali disease type).

Alkali disease occurs when animals consume moderate levels of Selenium for a period of weeks to months.

The usual clinical signs of chronic selenosis in horses, cattle, and swine are loss of hair (horses and cattle lose long hair from the mane and tails), emaciation, hoof lesions, weight reduction, and lameness.

questions.text: A patient presented with cheilitis, stomatitis, and a glove and stocking pattern of neuropathy. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described, including cheilitis, stomatitis, and glove and stocking pattern neuropathy, is most consistent with Vitamin B12 deficiency. This deficiency can lead to a condition known as pernicious anemia which presents with a variety of symptoms including those described.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurological manifestations such as peripheral neuropathy (glove and stocking pattern), as well as gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea. Additionally, vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, which may present with cheilitis and stomatitis.

Other options:

(a) Niacin (B3) deficiency: Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Cheilitis and stomatitis are common manifestations of pellagra, but glove and stocking pattern neuropathy are not typically associated with niacin deficiency.

(b) Thiamine (B1) deficiency: Thiamine deficiency can cause a condition known as beriberi, which can manifest with neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it usually does not present with dermatological symptoms like cheilitis and stomatitis.

(d) Riboflavin (B2) deficiency: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency can cause glossitis (inflammation of the tongue) and cheilosis (cracks or sores at the corners of the mouth). While riboflavin deficiency can cause dermatological symptoms, it is less likely to cause rashes in sun-exposed areas and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with a 2-week history of progressive severe headache and blurry vision. Clinical examination was significant for bilateral papilledema. A lumbar puncture revealed elevated opening pressure with normal CSF composition. An MRI showed no space-occupying lesions. On further questioning, she admits to taking high-dose multivitamin supplements. Which vitamin excess is likely to cause the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of increased intracranial pressure in the absence of space-occupying lesion points towards the diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri. Vitamin A excess is the likely cause.

Clinical features of hypervitaminosis A:

  • CNS: Symptoms of raised intracranial pressure (pseudotumor cerebri) such as headache, nausea, vomiting, blurring of vision, ataxia, anorexia
  • Liver: Hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia
  • Musculoskeletal: Thickening of the long bones (bony exostosis), hypercalcemia, soft tissue calcification
  • Dermatological: Dryness, exfoliative dermatitis, alopecia
  • Teratogenesis: Pregnant women should not ingest excessive quantities as it can cause congenital malformations in the developing fetus. Isotretinoin(13-cis retinoic acid) is a drug that is teratogenic and absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came to OPD with a tingling sensation in her legs and hands. The oral examination shows the following features. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing the riboflavin deficiency that this patient has. The image shows cheilosis and angular stomatitis which point towards riboflavin deficiency. The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase.

Deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  • Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin.
  • Glossitis: tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes: keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

questions.text: A 48-year old non-diabetic obese man presented for routine follow up. On investigation, his lipid profile showed hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated LDL and VLDL. Which of the following vitamins can be used as a lipid-lowering agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that can be used as a lipid-lowering agent is nicotinic acid (niacin or vitamin B3).

Niacin causes a reduction in LDL, VLDL and triglycerides along with an increase in HDL. It is the only lipid-lowering agent that lowers lipoprotein (a) levels significantly.

questions.text: A 39-year-old obese ,non-diabetic, non-hypertensive female presented with grade 2 fatty liver with hepatic fibrosis and inflammation. She has no history of smoking or drinking. A diagnosis of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has been made. Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Alpha tocopherol or vitamin E is the first line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medication), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, Methotrexate, Doxycycline, l-Asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is characterized by hepatic steatosis which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation. Currently, biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia).

Alpha tocopherol or vitamin E is the first line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In many studies, vitamin E was well-tolerated, showed modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

 Other options : 

N acetyl cysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via oral or intravenous route.

Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH as it has not been known to improve liver histology.

questions.text:
Which of the following biochemical parameters are correct in Vitamin D-dependent rickets?

Metabolic bone disease

 Serum calcium PTH level Serum phosphate Serum ALP
 A

Decreased/

Normal

 Normal Normal Normal

B

Decreased/

Normal

 Increased Decreased Increased

C

 Decreased Increased Increased Increased
 D  Increased  Increased  Decreased  Increased
questions.solution:
Lab investigations in rickets reveal normal/decreased serum calcium, decreased phosphorous, elevated PTH, and increased ALP levels.

Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decreased vitamin D leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased PTH production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

The interaction between these are given below:

Note:

Hypophosphatemic rickets is an X-linked dominant disease where mutation of PHEX gene leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased, leading to hypophosphatemia. As phosphorus is an important mineral needed in the formation and bone growth in children while strength in adults , it can also lead to rickets.

questions.text: An patient presented with bleeding gums and examination findings are as below. This given condition can be seen in deficiency of _________
questions.solution:
The given image shows perifollicular purpura. This along with corkscrew like body hair and bleeding gums is characteristic of  Scurvy (vitamin C deficiency).

  • Vitamin C is a water‐soluble vitamin, antioxidant and essential co‐factor for collagen biosynthesis, carnitine, and catecholamine metabolism, and dietary iron absorption.
  • Humans are unable to synthesize vitamin C; therefore, vitamin C is strictly obtained through the dietary intake of fruit and vegetables.
  • Scurvy develops 1–3 months after initiating a vitamin C deficient diet.
  • The cutaneous manifestations of scurvy include phrynoderma, corkscrew hairs, perifollicular hemorrhage and purpura, edema of the lower extremities, and splinter hemorrhages.
  • Corkscrew hairs represent fractured and coiled hairs due to impaired keratin cross‐links by disulfide bonds. With time, significant vascular congestion occurs, particularly in the lower extremities, leading to perifollicular hemorrhage and edema.

questions.text: A 20-year-old bodybuilder presented with fatigue on moderate exercise. He had recently started eating raw eggs for protein. Which of the following enzymes is likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The patient developed pyruvate carboxylase enzyme deficiency.

Individuals who eat an excess of uncooked egg-white, develop biotin deficiency and as a result deficiency of the carboxylase enzymes. This is because a protein called, avidin present in the egg-white binds to biotin in the diet, and makes biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption.

Biotin deficiency can cause:

  • Dermatitis
  • Mental status changes (depression, hallucinations)
  • Paraesthesia
  • Alopecia

Biotin serves as a co-enzyme for the synthesis of several carboxylase enzymes such as:

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
  • Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is breast milk deficient in?
questions.solution:
Breast milk is deficient in vitamin K.

Therefore infants have to be supplemented with vitamin K to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains many antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the baby's optimum growth as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

Components of breast milk and diseases they protect against:

Components of breast milk Protection against
Lysozyme
  • Escherichia coli, Salmonella
  • Entamoeba histolytica
Lactoferrin
  • E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
  • E. histolytica, Giardia lamblia
  • Plasmodium falciparum
  • Rotavirus
Bifidus factor E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
Low levels of para-aminobenzoic acid Plasmodium

Breastmilk is also deficient in vitamin D and exclusively breastfed infants can develop vitamin D deficiency unless adequately supplemented.

Human milk is a rich source of vitamin C and contains around 5-15mg/100cal. Vitamin C is found in higher levels in breast milk than in cow milk.

questions.text: A 5-year old child from a refugee camp presents with generalized oedema, tachycardia, and palpitations. Signs of heart failure are present and a chest X-ray reveals massive cardiomegaly. Lab markers reveal low RBC Trans-ketolase activity. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is likely to be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a child is suggestive of Wet Beri-beri. The vitamin deficiency associated with this condition is thiamine (Vitamin B1).

Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with Tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, edema. It is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice-based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Dry beri-beri is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

Thiamine deficiency can also be named based on the pattern of dietary deficiency seen. These would include, oriental beri-beri (diet predominantly including polished rice) and occidental Beri-beri (a diet rich in refined flours and food fads). The latter form is commonly seen in alcoholics.

Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about vitamin K?

choices.text: Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.
It is a water soluble vitamin.
Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.
Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

questions.solution:
Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency. 

Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to loss of normal bowel flora that synthesizes menaquinones (vitamin K2), a vitamer of vitamin K, thus leading to vitamin K deficiency.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin and its deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

Three compounds have the biological activity of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green vegetables.
  • Menaquinones (Vitamin K2) are synthesized by the intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) is a synthetic compound which is metabolized to phylloquinone.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficiency leading to this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial (perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A: Niacin deficiency leads to Pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is seen in sun-exposed areas and presents as hyperpigmentation around the neck known as Casal's necklace. An image of Casal's necklace is shown below.

Option C: Riboflavin deficiency manifests as glossitis, cheilitis, magenta-colored tongue, angular stomatitis, and circumcorneal vascularization, as shown below.

Option D: Selenium deficiency is implicated in keshan disease (Endemic cardiomyopathy) and kashin-Beck disease (Chronic, endemic osteoarthropathy).

questions.text: Which among the following helps in the maturation of collagen?
questions.solution:
Ascorbic acid/Vitamin C helps in the maturation of collagen. 

Collagen is synthesized intracellularly in fibroblasts. Each polypeptide chain of collagen has about 1000 amino acid residues composed of Glycine-X-Y repeats, where X and Y are proline and hydroxyproline predominantly.

Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues takes place intracellularly as a part of post-translational modification with the help of prolyl hydroxylase and lysyl hydroxylase. These enzymes require iron in a reduced state in its active site. Vitamin C/ascorbic acid keeps iron in a reduced state in these enzymes and thus helps in the maturation of collagen. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy which is characterized by bleeding tendencies, anemia, and skeletal abnormalities due to defective collagen in the connective tissue.

Steps of post-translational modification of collagen includes

  • Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues
  • Glycosylation of hydroxylysine residues
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain disulfide bonds
  • Triple helix formation
  • Cleavage of 25–35 kDa portions at both carboxy and amino terminal end
  • Quartered staggered arrangement
  • Oxidative deamination of lysine and hydroxylysine residues
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain crosslinks

Other options:

Option B: Lysyl oxidase is a copper-containing enzyme that helps in covalent crosslinking collagen fibers. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase, and reduced cross-linkage of collagen leading to a condition called Menke's disease. Zinc has no role in collagen maturation.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency.

The most common cause of blindness (including adults), is however, cataract.

questions.text:
The skin condition shown in the image is treated by supplementation of:
a. Safflower oil.
b. Vitamin K.
c. Vitamin B complex.
questions.solution:
The above skin condition is known as Phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of Safflower oil and Vitamin B complex.

The deficiency of essential fatty acid is associated with rough and dry skin, known as Phrynoderma or toad skin. It is a type of follicular hyperkeratosis.It is caused by generalised malnutrition and Vit. E,B,A and C and is seen commonly in African and Asian communities. Riboflavin is required for pyridoxine metabolism, which, in turn, is required for tryptophan-niacin metabolism, and niacin is necessary for fatty acid synthesis. This explains the combination therapy of EFA and Vitamin B complex.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was examined in a village camp. The child had a poor appetite and visible peripheral edema. The hair was sparse and easily pluckable. The skin showed peeling as shown below.  What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette of a child with poor appetite, sparse easily pluckable hair, and the image showing flaky paint dermatosis are suggestive of Kwashiorkar.

Kwashiorkor results due to severe protein and essential amino acid deprivation along with adequate calorie intake. It is particularly seen in children at the time of weaning, to a diet consisting majorly of corn, rice, or beans. 

The clinical features include a classic cutaneous finding of diffuse reddish-brown scaling dermatosis that has been likened to cracked skin, peeling paint, enamel paint, flaky paint, or crazy paving. This is due to the typical scaling and irregular fissuring. Nails are thin and soft. Hairs are thin and sparse and display a flag sign consisting of alternative light and dark bands of hair. The consistent feature is peripheral edema due to the associated hypoproteinaemia. Edema of the face results in moon facies. Abdominal distention (pot belly) is a feature and is due to hepatomegaly from increased fatty deposition due to a lack of available apolipoproteins.

Other options:

Option A: Marasmus results due to global macro-nutrient deficiency, which leads to growth retardation with <60% of ideal body weight. Loss of subcutaneous tissue, growth stunting, dyspigmentation, and desquamative changes are seen in these patients. Marasmus patients do not demonstrate hypoproteinaemia or edema. There is distension of the abdomen due to hypotonia of the abdominal musculature. These patients typically have wrinkled, loose, and dry skin. The hair and nails often grow slowly and may show brittleness. The hair falls out easily and often shows features of alopecia.

Below is the image of a child with marasmus.

Option B: Pellagra results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). It is characterized by the classic presentation of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck, which is a characteristic feature seen in pellagra.

Below is the image showing Casal's necklace.

Option C: Vitamin A deficiency can result in phrynoderma that is characterized by keratotic follicular papules along the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral arms. It is seen in the deficiency of vitamin B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids as well.

Below is the image showing phrynoderma.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: Which of the following mineral is absorbed by the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte by mucosal block theory.

Iron Absorption :

Iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1. (DMT-1)

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Clinical significance - Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed.

Iron absorption in the duodenum is mainly regulated by hepcidin. It inhibits ferroportin and suppresses the release of iron from macrophages which is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

questions.text: The co-factor for glutathione peroxidase is __
questions.solution:
Selenium act as a cofactor for glutathione peroxidase.

Glutathione peroxidases:

  • Also known as selenoproteins
  • Selenium-containing glutathione peroxidases help transform hydrogen peroxide into harmless water (antioxidant action)
  • Selenium deficiency results in Impaired function of glutathione peroxidases. As a result, destructive hydrogen peroxide breaks down into even more dangerous hydroxyl radicals which damage cell membranes and cell DNA leading to serious disease

Selenium:

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine.

There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as:

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Selenium deficiency is implicated in keshan disease (Endemic cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (Chronic, endemic osteoarthropathy.

questions.text: RDA of vitamin A in a 6 year old child is _______
questions.solution:
RDA of vitamin A in a 6 year old child is  400mcg/day.

Sources of Vitamin A:

  • Animal source: liver, egg, butter, milk, fish, meat
  • Richest plant source: Carrot
  • Richest source: halibut liver oil (fish oil)

questions.text: FMN and FAD are coenzymes derived from ______
questions.solution:
Coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) are derived from Riboflavin (vitamin B2).

FMN-coenzyme role:

  • Complex I in electron transport chain (ETC): NADH-Q oxidoreductase, NADH dehydrogenase
  • L-amino acid oxidase

FAD-coenzyme role:

  • TCA cycle: Succinate dehydrogenase (complex II in ETC)
  • Fatty acid oxidation: Acyl CoA dehydrogenase
  • Amino acid metabolism: D-amino acid oxidase
  • Xanthine oxidase
